title: 108_s1837
content: The Act may be cited as the "Combating Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Act of 2003". Specified activities for money laundering are outlined in the Act. The Act, known as the "Combating Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Act of 2003", includes amendments to the RICO definitions in Section 1961(1) of title 18, United States Code. These amendments involve various criminal activities such as burglary, embezzlement, illegal money transmitters, and fraud in the purchase or sale of securities. Additionally, changes are made to monetary investments in Section 1956(c)(7)(D) of the same code. The United States Code is amended to include financing of terrorism and violations of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. Section 1956(e) of title 18 is also amended to allow investigations by the Department of Justice and the Department of the Treasury. The Secretary of the Treasury, Secretary of Homeland Security, Commissioner of Social Security, and Postmaster General may direct actions for offenses under their respective jurisdictions. This authority must be exercised according to an agreement between the relevant parties. The Attorney General may direct investigations for violations of the law involving offenses described in subsection (c)(7)(E), while the Secretary of the Treasury and Secretary of Homeland Security may direct investigations for property from unlawful activity. The Department of Justice, Department of the Treasury, and Department of Homeland Security may investigate these violations as appropriate. The Secretary of Homeland Security, the Secretary of the Treasury, and the Postmaster General may direct investigations for offenses under their jurisdiction, in accordance with an agreement involving the Attorney General. SEC. 3. ILLEGAL MONEY TRANSMITTING BUSINESSES. Technical amendments are made to Section 1960 of title 18, United States Code, changing "unlicensed" to "illegal" in various subsections. Additionally, a prohibition on unlicensed money transmitting businesses is added, and authority to investigate is granted. The amendment allows for investigations by the Attorney General, Secretary of the Treasury, and Secretary of Homeland Security for violations of the section. SEC. 4. ASSETS OF PERSONS COMMITTING TERRORIST ACTS AGAINST FOREIGN COUNTRIES OR INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS. Section 981(a)(1)(G) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include forfeiture of property belonging to individuals, entities, or organizations involved in planning or carrying out acts of international terrorism against international organizations or foreign governments. The amendment to Section 981(a)(1)(G) of title 18, United States Code, allows for the forfeiture of property related to individuals, entities, or organizations involved in planning or carrying out acts of international terrorism outside the US, as long as there is a connection to the jurisdiction of the United States. SEC. 5 amends Section 1956(a) of title 18, US Code to include transactions involving proceeds of unlawful activity in a single plan. SEC. 6 makes technical corrections to the financing of terrorism statute. Section 2339C of title 18, United States Code is amended to include provisions regarding concealment and definitions related to the support or resources provided for unlawful activities. The term 'material support or resources' is defined in section 2339A(b) of title 18, United States Code. Section 2332b(g)(5)(B) is amended to include references to section 2339C regarding financing of terrorism. SEC. 7. MISCELLANEOUS AND TECHNICAL AMENDMENTS. Amendments are made to criminal forfeiture and technical sections of the United States Code, including changes to definitions and terminology related to unlawful activity and property from unlawful activity. Amendments to the United States Code include redefining the term "conducts" and updating obstruction of justice laws. SEC. 8. Extension of the Money Laundering and Financial Crimes Strategy Act of 1998 includes amending sections of the United States Code to extend appropriations for fiscal years 2004, 2005, and 2006 by $15,000,000 each.
